page.title: 16Local Roman History
page.content: At Old House Farm (16th C or earlier) a Roman well was excavated in 1939 by S.E.Winbolt; he found enough potsherds to suggest a Roman Villa. Also, oyster shells were found in 2 nearby fields. No structures remain today. The site lies about 320 yards southwest of the Farm between two large lush meadows at different levels, surrounded by huge oak and ash trees. The spring never runs dry. In 1940 Roman pottery was found at adjacent Sproutes Farm. These finds went to the Sussex Archeological Society at Barbican House, Lewes. Lignite is present in the stream between Old House Farm and Gay Street, and this with other minerals in the area could be a reason for the early Roman/Saxon settlement along nearby Stane Street. Roman coins were found at Gaywood, and a Roman tile factory was excavated at nearby Itchingfield.
